column1: Papua is the largest and easternmost province of Indonesia
column2: comprising most of Western New Guinea. It is bordered by the state of Papua New Guinea to the east
column3: the province of West Papua to the west
column4: the Pacific Ocean to the north
column5: and the Arafura Sea to the south. According to the 2010 census by Statistics Indonesia
column9: the majority of whom are Christians. The 2015 Intermediate Census revealed a population of 3

column14: 302. The province is divided into twenty-eight regencies and one city. Its capital and largest city is Jayapura.

column1: The province was formerly called Irian Jaya and comprised the entire Western New Guinea until the inauguration of the province of West Papua (then West Irian Jaya) in 2001. In 2002
column2: Papua adopted its current name and was granted a special autonomous status under Indonesian legislation. Puncak Jaya is the province's highest mountain and the highest point in Indonesia.

column1: Indonesia proclaimed its independence in 1945 and claimed all of the territory of the former Dutch East Indies
column2: including Western New Guinea. However
column3: the region was retained by the Netherlands until the mid-1960s
column4: which caused Indonesia to repeatedly launch military operations there. It was agreed through the New York Agreement in 1962 that the administration of Western New Guinea would be temporarily transferred from the Netherlands to Indonesia and that by 1969 the United Nations should oversee a referendum of the Papuan people
column5: in which they would be given two options: to remain part of Indonesia or to become an independent nation. This vote was referred to as the Act of Free Choice. The referendum was recognised by the international community and the region became the Indonesian province of Irian Jaya. The province has been renamed as Papua since 2002.In January 2003 President Megawati Sukarnoputri signed an order dividing Papua into three provinces: Central Irian Jaya (Irian Jaya Tengah)
column8: and West Papua (Irian Jaya Barat). The formality of installing a local government for Jaraka in Irian Jaya Barat (West) took place in February 2003 and a governor was appointed in November; a government for Irian Jaya Tengah (Central Irian Jaya) was delayed from August 2003 due to violent local protests. The creation of this separate Central Irian Jaya Province was blocked by Indonesian courts
column9: who declared it to be unconstitutional and in contravention of the Papua's special autonomy agreement. The previous division into two provinces was allowed to stand as an established fact.

column1: The province of Papua is governed by a directly elected governor (currently Lukas Enembe) and a regional legislature
column2: People's Representative Council of province of Papua (Dewan Perwakilan Rakyat Papua). A government organisation that only exists in Papua is the Papuan People's Council (Majelis Rakyat Papua)
column3: which was formed by the Indonesian Government in 2005 as a coalition of Papuan tribal chiefs
column4: tasked with arbitration and speaking on behalf of Papuan tribal customs.

column1: The province of Papua is one of three provinces to have obtained special autonomy status
column2: the others being Aceh and West Papua. According to Law 21/2001 on Special Autonomy Status (UU Nomor 21 Tahun 2001 tentang Otonomi khusus Papua)
column3: the provincial government of Papua is provided with authority within all sectors of administration
column4: except for the five strategic areas of foreign affairs
column7: religion and justice. The provincial government is authorised to issue local regulations to further stipulate the implementation of the special autonomy
column8: including regulating the authority of districts and municipalities within the province. Due to its special autonomy status
column9: Papua province is provided with significant amount of special autonomy funds
column10: which can be used to benefit its indigenous peoples. But the province has low fiscal capacity and it is highly dependent on unconditional transfers and the above-mentioned special autonomy fund
column11: which accounted for about 55% of total revenues in 2008.

column1: After obtaining its special autonomy status
column2: in order to allow the local population access to timber production benefits
column3: the Papuan provincial government issued a number of decrees
column4: enabling:

column1: a Timber Logging Permit for Customary Communities
column2: which enabled local people to carry out timber extraction in small concessions (250 to 1
column3: 000 hectares) for one year through a community-based or participatory community cooperative;

column1: a Permit to Manage Customary Forests
column2: which was a timber extraction permit for larger concessions (up to 2
column3: 000 hectares) for a maximum of 20 years;

column1: logging companies had to pay compensations to local communities in addition to all other fees and taxes collected by the national government.
As of 2010 (following the separation of West Papua Province in 2003)

column1: The city of Jayapura also has the status of an autonomous city
column2: equal to a regency. It was founded on 7 March 1910 as Hollandia and is the capital. Since Indonesian administration the name of the city has been changed to Kotabaru
column3: then to Sukarnopura before its current name
column4: Jayapura. Jayapura is also the largest city of Papua Province
column5: with a small but active tourism industry. It is built on a slope overlooking the bay. Cenderawasih University (UNCEN) campus at Abepura houses the University Museum where some of the Asmat artifacts collected by Michael Rockefeller are stored. Both Tanjung Ria beach
column6: near the market at Hamadi – site of 22 April 1944 Allied invasion during World War II – and the site of General Douglas MacArthur's World War II headquarters at Ifar Gunung have monuments commemorating the events.

column1: A central east–west mountain range dominates the geography of the island of New Guinea

column4: 000 mi) in total length. The western section is around 600 km (400 mi) long and 100 km (60 mi) across. The province contains the highest mountains between the Himalayas and the Andes

column1: The southern and northern lowlands stretch for hundreds of kilometres and include lowland rainforests
column2: extensive wetlands
column3: savanna grasslands
column4: and expanses of mangrove forest. The southern lowlands are the site of Lorentz National Park
column5: also a UNESCO World Heritage Site.The province's largest river is the Mamberamo located in the northern part of the province. The result is a large area of lakes and rivers known as the Lakes Plains region. The Baliem Valley

column1: Papua province has a fertility rate of 2.9 children per woman The population grew from the 1.94 million recorded in the 2000 Indonesia Census
column2: to 2.83 million as recorded by the 2010 Census
column3: and is officially estimated to be at about 3
column5: 100 in mid 2019. From the early 1990s until the mid 2010s
column6: Papua had the highest population growth rate of all Indonesian provinces at over 3% annually. This was partly a result of birth rates
column7: but mainly due to migration from other parts of Indonesia. An overwhelming percentage of these migrants came as part of a government-sponsored transmigration program.

column1: The following are some of the most well-known ethnic groups of Papua:
The Yei (pronounced Yay) are sometimes known as the Jei
column2: Je
column3: Yei-nan people.

column2: 500 speakers of the Yei language. 40% Ethno Religionists- animistic tribal religion 60% Catholics and other Christians (blended with animistic beliefs & customs):

column1: The Yei language is believed to have two dialects observed by a Wycliffe
column2: SIL language survey in 2001. At home the Yei people speak their own language but use Indonesian for trade
column3: wider communication and at school. Most Yei are literate in Indonesian.

column1: There are elementary schools in each village. About 10–30% of children continue in middle school. Very few go to high school.
The nearest high school is in Merauke city.

column2: fishing
column3: and gardening short and long term crops in the lowlands. The Yei diet mainly consists of rice
column4: vegetables

column1: With their land at an altitude of less than 100 meters above sea level
column2: the Yei people can best be accessed by vehicle on the road from Merauke or by motorized canoe up the Maro River. There is no airstrip or airplane access other than float plane which is currently available from Merauke through MAF by about a 15-minute flight to Toray.

column1: The Poo and Bupul villages have a clinic but people still use traditional medicines.
There is very little infrastructure in the area: no telephones or toilets. At night electricity is run from a generator. There are single side-band radios (SSBs) in Bupul

column2: 83.15% of the Papuans identified themselves as Christian with 65.48% being Protestant and 17.67% being Roman Catholic. 15.88% of the population was Muslim and less than 1% were Buddhist or Hindu. There is also substantial practice of animism
column3: the traditional religion for many Papuans
column4: with many blending animistic beliefs with other religions such as Christianity.
